Television has greatly expanded the kind of
teaching resources Barfield is able to draw on. In
a lesson on the muscular system, he brings an
archery champion before the cameras. To demon¬
strate dental hygiene, he has a dentist come in
and brush his teeth in plain view of thousands
of students. Another lesson consisted of a noted
surgeon and a full complement of nurses and as¬
sistants re-enacting an appendectomy.
The hands of Myles Platt became as familiar to
Detroit high-school students as did the hands of
Frank Costello to millions of Americans during
nationally televised crime hearings eleven years
ago. One of Platt’s notable lessons concerned the
struggle among England, France, and the Holy
Roman Empire in the sixteenth century. The
camera showed only his hands against a map. The
hands moved blocks marked for Henry VIII,
Francis I, and Charles V as Platt discussed the
balance of power. He has also used this technique
in describing the role of Joan of Arc in the Battle
of Orleans.
But ingenious effects and objects are only one as¬
pect of the drama unfolding in education through
the use of television. Platt’s case, for example,
illustrates ETV’s ability to extend to many more
students teaching that is good to begin with. A
